conclusion: To solve the problem, use properties of similar triangles and given distances to find the refractive index.

The image shows a quarter-circle cross-section of a glass column with radius R. A beam of light enters from point P on the arc, hits the interface BC, and exits at point M. The distance from P to the line AC is given as (sqrt(3)R)/2, and MC = (sqrt(3)R)/3.
Identify the given distances: PM = (sqrt(3)R)/2 and MC = (sqrt(3)R)/3.
Calculate PC using the Pythagorean theorem in triangle PCM: PC = sqrt((PM)^2 - (MC)^2) = R/2.
Recognize that triangles PAB and PCM are similar because angle PAB = angle PCM and angle P = angle P.
Use the similarity of triangles to set up the proportion: PM/PC = R/AB.
Solve for AB: sqrt(3)/1 = R/AB implies AB = R/sqrt(3).
Use the formula for refractive index n = PM/PC: n = (sqrt(3)R/2)/(R/2) = sqrt(3).
The refractive index of the glass column is sqrt(3).
